facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 144 of 1961 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDiCTION Criminal Appeal No. 144 of 1961. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 8, 1961, of the Mysore High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 362 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgmEnt and order dated March 8, 1961, of the Mysore High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 362 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 9, 1962 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962 November 9. The judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-The only question for decision in this appeal

facts.text: Appellant was employed as a Head Constable at the Kalkeri Outpost attached to the Hippussagi Police Station in February 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In February 1954, the appellant was employed as a Head Constable at the Kalkeri Outpost attached to the Hippussagi Police Station.

facts.text: On February 23, 1954, the appellant went to Budhihal Road on receipt of information about smuggling of Ganja from Hyderabad State to Kalkeri.

anchor.surface_text: On February 23, 1954, the appellant went to Budhihal Road on receipt of information about the smuggling of Ganja from the then Hyderabad State to Kalkeri

facts.text: At about 2 or 3 p.m. on February 23, 1954, appellant caught Nabi Sab Kembhavi with a bundle containing 15 packets of Ganja.

anchor.surface_text: and at about 2 or 3 p.m. actually caught one Nabi Sab Kembhavi with a bundle companytaining 15 packets of Ganja.

facts.text: 15 packets of Ganja were seized by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: These 15 packets of Ganja were seized and for this seizure the appellant prepared a Panchnama

facts.text: Appellant prepared a Panchnama incorrectly showing seizure of only 9 packets of Ganja.

anchor.surface_text: in which however he incorrectly showed the seizure of 9 packets of Ganja only.

facts.text: On February 24, 1954, appellant had a new Panchnama prepared falsely reciting that a person running towards Budhihal threw away a bundle containing 9 packets of Ganja.

anchor.surface_text: On. February 24, 1954, it is alleged, the appellant had a new Panchnama prepared in which it was falsely recited that a person who was companying towards the village of Budhihal ran away on seeing the Panchas and the Havaldar, after throwing away a bundle and this bundle was found to companytain 9 packets of Ganja weighing one tola each.

facts.text: The new Panchnama dated it as February 23, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The date in the Panchnama was mentioned as February 23, 1954.

facts.text: A report was prepared to the same false effect.

anchor.surface_text: A report to the same effect was also prepared.

facts.text: Prosecution case: Panchnama and report falsely prepared by appellant to save Nabi Sab Kembhavi from punishment.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that numbersuch thing happened on February 24 , 1954, or February 23, 1954 but that this Panchnama and the report were falsely prepared by the appellant with the dishonest intention of saving Nabi Sab Kembhavi who had actually been caught with Ganja from legal punishment.

facts.text: Appellant tried by Additional Sessions Judge, Bijapur, on charge under s. 218 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On these allegations the appellant was tried by the Additional Sessions judge, Bijapur, on a charge under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded not guilty and contended that the Panchnama and report were correctly prepared on February 23, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: He pleaded number guilty and companytended that the Panchnama and the report which are challenged by the prosecution as a false Panchnama were companyrectly prepared by him on February 23. 1954, and mention the true state of affairs

facts.text: Appellant raised defence under Rule 542 of Bombay Police Manual requiring prior permission of District Superintendent of Police.

anchor.surface_text: is It was also pleaded that Rule 542 of the Bombay Police Manual barred his prosecution as prior permission of the District Superintendent of Police had number been taken.

facts.text: Appellant raised defence that prosecution barred by s.161(1) Bombay Police Act as commenced after six months.

anchor.surface_text: A further defence was raised that in any case as the prosecution was companymenced long after six months had elapsed after the alleged companymission of the offence it was barred by s.161 1  of the Bombay Police Act.

facts.text: Trial Court convicted appellant under s.218 IPC and sentenced to 1 year RI.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant. was however companyvicted by the Trial Court under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Mysore High Court, which dismissed the appeal agreeing with trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order,, he appealed to the High Court of Mysore. The High Court agreed with the Trial Court that an offence under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code had been made out. ... Accordingly, the High Court dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Mysore HC rejected defence under Rule 542 as no statutory force.

anchor.surface_text: The defence under. Rule 542 of the Bombay Police Manual was also rejected on the ground that this Rule had numberstatutory force.

facts.text: Mysore HC held prosecution not barred by s.161(1) as acts on Feb 24 related to duty from Feb 23.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the plea of limitation under s. 161 1  of the Bombay Police Act, 1951, the High Court was of the opinion that on February 24. 1954, the appellant had duty to perform in regard to the crime detected on the 23rd

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave for appeal on limitation issue under s.161(1) Bombay Police Act.

anchor.surface_text: Against that decision the present appeal has been preferred by special leave granted by this Court and the only question raised in the appeal is as regards the companyrectness of the High Courts companyclusion

facts.text: Prosecution instituted more than six months after the act complained of.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the prosecution was admittedly instituted much more than six months after the date of the act companyplained of.

facts.text: Offence alleged committed by preparation of false Panchnama and report on February 24, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: From what has been said above about the prosecution allegations it is clear that the offence is alleged to have been companymitted, by the preparation of a False Panchnama and a false report on February 24, 1954.

facts.text: Preparation of correct Panchnama and true report regarding seizure is duty of police officer under Bombay Police Act s.64.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that die preparation of a. companyrect Panchnama and a true report as, regards the seizure the Ganja was, the duty of the police officer. ... For s. 64 of the Act provides inter alia that it shall be the duty of every police officer,

facts.text: Appellant authorized under Bombay Prohibition Act to seize Ganja.

anchor.surface_text: That the appellant was an officer authorised under the Bombay Prohibition Act to seize the Ganja in the circumstances, alleged is clear.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that preparation of false Panchnama and report done under colour of duty, so prosecution barred by s.161(1).

anchor.surface_text: We have companye to the companyclusion that on a proper interpretation of the words under companyour of duty, the acts in respect of which the prosecution was, instituted were acts done under companyour of duty imposed upon him by the Police Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.161(1) applies to offences under IPC, not limited to Police Act.

anchor.surface_text: It must accordingly be held that the prosecution against the appellant should have been dismissed in accordance with the provisions of s. 161 1  of the Bombay Police Act.
Appeal by special leave from the judgmEnt and order dated March 8, 1961, of the Mysore High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 362 of 1959.
Against that decision the present appeal has been preferred by special leave granted by this Court
on a charge under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.

concepts.unlisted_description: Limitation of six months for prosecution of police officer for acts done under colour or in excess of duty

anchor.surface_text: s. 161 1  of the Bombay Police Act, 1951,

concepts.unlisted_description: Limitation of six months for prosecution of police officer for acts done under colour or in excess of duty

anchor.surface_text: Section 161 1  is in these words- 161 1 . In any case of alleged offence by the Revenue Commissioner,, the Commissioner, a Magistrate, Police Officer or other person, or of a wrong alleged to have been done by such Revenue Commissioner, Commissioner, Magistrate Police Officer or other person, by any act done under colour or in excess of any such duty or authority as aforesaid, or wherein it shall appear to the Court that the offence or wrong if committed or done was of the character aforesaid,. the prosecution or suit shall not be entertained, or-shall be dismissed, if instituted more than six months after the date of the act complained of.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to offences under IPC if act done under colour or in excess of duty; prosecution barred if after 6 months

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preparation of false Panchnama and report constituted acts done under colour of duty imposed by Police Act; prosecution instituted after six months hence barred.

holdings.text: the acts in respect of which the prosecution was instituted were acts done under colour of duty imposed upon him by the Police Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have come to the conclusion that on a proper interpretation of the words under colour of duty, the acts in respect of which the prosecution was instituted were acts done under colour of duty imposed upon him by the Police Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: False preparation uses legal duty as cloak or veil even if corrupt or in dereliction; follows precedents like Narayan Hari.

holdings.text: when the preparation of a correct Panchnama and a true report as regards the seizure is the duty of the police officer concerned, he prepares instead a false Panchnama and a false report, that act is done by him under colour or in excess of that duty.

anchor.surface_text: The question still to be considered therefore is whether when the preparation of a correct Panchnama and a true report as regards the seizure is the duty of the police officer concerned, he prepares instead a false Panchnama and a false report, that act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act bears colour of duty when office used as pretence or cloak for falsehood, per lexicons and common usage; dereliction does not remove colour.

holdings.text: the preparation of a correct Panchnama and a true report as regards the seizure the Ganja was, the duty of the police officer.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the preparation of a. correct Panchnama and a true report as regards the seizure the Ganja was, the duty of the police officer. It is equally clear that such preparation was the duty of the police officer as laid down in the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Duty imposed by s.64 Bombay Police Act to lay information and take steps to bring offenders to justice; appellant authorised under Prohibition Act.

holdings.text: the word offence as used in s. 161 1  clearly includes an offence under the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: Offence has been defined in the Bombay General Clauses Act to mean any act or omission made punishable by any law for the time being in force. On this definition the word offence as used in s. 161 1  clearly includes an offence under the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad definition in General Clauses Act; deliberate wide language unlike s.150; applies to offences under any law.

holdings.text: even though the act was done in deliberate disregard of his proper duty and authority the act was one done under colour or in excess of a duty imposed or an authority conferred on him by the Police Act.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was considered by a Full Bench of the Bombay High Court in Narayan Hari v. Yeswant Raoji 2 . There the allegation against the police officer was that while investigating a case he had deliberately taken down the statement of a witness

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full Bench decision in Narayan Hari correctly interprets 'under colour of duty' for s.167/218 IPC acts.

holdings.text: the view that if the alleged act is found to have been done in gross violation of the duty then it ceased to be an act done under colour, is not correct.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel drew our attention to another decision of the Bombay High Court in Parbat Gopal Walekar v. Dinkar Shinde 1  where the act of a police constable in driving rashly and negligently when driving a police jeep which was carrying

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gross violation does not remove colour of duty; question arises precisely when act violates duty; distinguishes facts of Parbat Gopal.

edges.explanation: The holding that 'offence' in s.161 includes IPC offences directly addresses the issue of whether s.161(1) is limited to offences against the Act with no application to IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Offence has been defined in the Bombay General Clauses Act to mean any act or omission made punishable by any law for the time being in force. On this definition the word offence as used in s. 161 1  clearly includes an offence under the Indian Penal Code.
It must accordingly be held that the prosecution against the appellant should have been dismissed in accordance with the provisions of s. 161 1  of the Bombay Police Act.
